p.s: The poem Sonnet 60 written by William Shakespeare and published on an unknown date deals with the role of time in human life.
The sonnet is a poem with 14 lines, each containing 10 or 11 syllables, and a fixed scheme.
It is arranged in three quatrains and a couplet, cross rhyming and written in iambic pentameter.
In the first quatrain the lyrical I, which is Shakespeare, describes how time has an influence on our world.
Through the use of the personification minutes hasten (l. 2) he expresses that time is running away.
This time would run away like waves makes towards the pebbled shore (l. 1).
Shakespeare compares the time to the movement of waves at the coast through this simile.
Furthermore, he states that sequent toil all forwards (l. 4) would content which means that hard work change seomthing and is also an aspect of time.
In the second quatrain the lyrical I describes the development of a human from birth to death.

The alliteration of c in crawls to maturity (l. 6) and crooked eclipses (l. 7) stresses the point that a human after his birth first moves forward very slowly to maturity and in goes with a crokked back in his last years.
The line and time that gave doth now his gift confound (l. 8) makes clear that after the death of a person her inheritage gets confused through time.
This development underlines his opinion that time has an important influence on human life.
In the third quatrain Shakespeare firstly adressesaddresses his beloved person with the personal pronoun youth (l. 9).
The lyrical I states that time would change the flourish set on youth (l. 9) but there are parallels in beauty's brow (l. 10).
He wants to express that time changes a person and her beauty but there are still parallels and the character of a person always stays the same.
Through using the parallelism of And (ll. 8, 10, 12, 13) at the beginning of a line the author draws the reader's attention to the influences time has.
In the final couplet Shakespeare wishes that his verse also will stand in far away times.
Through the use of the alliteration shall stand (l. 13) the underlines this hope.
The function of hissonnet would be to Praising thy worth (l. 14) what means that the lyrical I wants to show admiration for his beloved person even if there is the cruel hand (l. 14) of time.
All in all, you can assume that Shakespeare wrote his sonnet his beloved person to show her that time is the dominant factor in life but the beauty of her and this verse too won't change ever.
